items.title: domain ending in . not recognized
items.body:
I'm parsing a series of request logs from a web crawl, and one of the URLs has a domain that surprisingly ends in a period, 'https://www.pendleton-usa.com./etc'. Web browsers seem to handle this request fine, but TLD crashes with:

`Domain pendleton-usa.com. didn't match any existing TLD name!`

Since such domains work as standard DNS queries, perhaps they should be supported by this library too.

items.title: Python 2 compatibility is broken by typing module
items.body:
There is no typing module in standard library of Python 2; to use typing in Python 2 , the backport pypi module typing should be added to install_requires explicitly:

https://pypi.org/project/typing/

https://github.com/barseghyanartur/tld/blob/master/setup.py#L79

Currently, tld can be installed successfully in Python 2 environment, but when you try to import it:
`ImportError: No module named typing`
is raised.

Add requirment 'typing;python_version<"3.5"' to setup.py might fix this issue.

items.title: Allow user to indicate where the TLD file is located
items.body:
In some of my use cases, being a web crawler for research, I need to have a fixed definition of the TLD across time (sometimes several years). Until then, we just passed a fixed version of the tlds to our internal functions. But now we are migrating to your lib and would like to be able to do the same.

I therefore propose:

1. To get rid of the `conf` module
2. To make the `update_tld_names` function simply take the target url and path location as argument and give it your defaults
3. To add a function such as `set_tld_names_location` or something of the kind, taking a custom path on the user's computer.

What do you think?

items.title: update-tld-names returns a non-zero exit code on success
items.body: Since the `console_scripts` entry point was introduced for `update-tld-names`, the executable returns a non-zero code on success, and zero on failure, which has opposite semantics to the usual process return codes.

items.title: What to do with url containing only the tld?
items.body:
@barseghyanartur I have a question: what should we do with urls such as:

```
http://cloud.fedoraproject.org
```

where the whole domain string is just a tld?

I know those cases are edge and probably illegal but they do work in browsers. Currently return values for those cases are not consistent (either a false or empty or return value).

I propose we return the the tld and blank the domain/subdomain etc.

items.title: tld.get_tld_names() documented as returning iterable, but Trie object is not iterable
items.body:
I use this package in a number of places for both personal and work projects; firstly I would just like to say thank you for sharing your hard work!

`get_tld_names()` in previous versions returned an iterable, and is still documented as doing so. I'm not exactly sure which version it was introduced in, however, in the latest version (v0.9 at time of writing), this function returns a Trie object.

Looking through the source code, it appears that the Trie class is not implemented in a way that makes it iterable (previous implementation used a built-in `set()` data structure). If I have additional time I will try to provide a pull request, however, work has been leaving very little free-time lately.

Thank you again!

items.title: active_only option seems erroneous
items.body:
Hello @barseghyanartur.

The `active_only` option seems erroneous. What I mean is that the `!` sigil before a fragment does not mean it's an inactive tld. It's just an exception over previous wildcard `*` rules. This option should be dropped and we should handle this correctly.

From the Public Suffix List [site](https://publicsuffix.org/list/):

> An exclamation mark (!) at the start of a rule marks an exception to a previous wildcard rule. An exception rule takes priority over any other matching rule.

Taking a Japanese example:

```
*.kawasaki.jp
*.kitakyushu.jp
*.kobe.jp
*.nagoya.jp
*.sapporo.jp
*.sendai.jp
*.yokohama.jp
!city.kawasaki.jp
!city.kitakyushu.jp
!city.kobe.jp
!city.nagoya.jp
!city.sapporo.jp
!city.sendai.jp
!city.yokohama.jp
```

```python
get_tld('http://www.help.kawasaki.jp')
# should yield 'help.kawasaki.jp'

get_tld('http://www.city.kawasaki.jp')
# should yield 'kawasaki.jp'
```

items.title: Concerning the TLD definition

milestone.description:
- [ ] Separate public and private TLDs.
- [ ] Redefine the TLD (according to acknowledged terms). Define a ``get_fld`` function to provide current default behaviour.
- [ ] Make a ``is_tld`` and ``is_fld`` functions.

items.body:
Hello @barseghyanartur. While implementing the Trie I stumbled upon something weird: in your example:

```python
get_tld("http://www.google.co.uk")
# 'google.co.uk'
```

Shouldn't the returned TLD be `co.uk` instead? Am I misunderstanding something about TLDs here? Seems you return domain origin + TLD, no?

items.title: Move to a Trie to match tlds
items.body:
Hello @barseghyanartur.

It is possible to enhance the performance and maybe memory footprint of your library (although I am not completely sure since needing more objects might be more RAM costly than just having a ~10k items hashset) by storing the tlds in a Trie in reverse order. This would mean more straightforward queries (just need to query the Trie to find the tld + more efficient misses if the query is not a tld etc.). I am not completely sure it would be more efficient though because it may mean more set/dict lookups than the current version but it depends on the average number of stems in the domain string.

What do you think? I can draft a PR to implement this if you feel this is a good way to go.

items.title: Differences with john-kurkowski/tldextract
items.body:
What are the differences of this package with respect to https://github.com/john-kurkowski/tldextract

Why do we need another one?

Thanks anyway for your package

items.title: Mix of public and private suffixes

milestone.description:
- [ ] Separate public and private TLDs.
- [ ] Redefine the TLD (according to acknowledged terms). Define a ``get_fld`` function to provide current default behaviour.
- [ ] Make a ``is_tld`` and ``is_fld`` functions.

items.body:
As the public suffix list is used to find the "TLD" (which is not the TLD in many cases), also private domains are now returned as TLD. Have a look at the list: https://publicsuffix.org/list/effective_tld_names.dat or https://publicsuffix.org/list/public_suffix_list.dat.

It is split into two sections, the public and the private suffixes. In the readme there is perfect example about how this get's wrong. The private suffixes can be submitted by every domain owner.

Eg. `co.uk` is a public suffix. A private suffix is e.g. `appspot.com`.

I see two issues here:
1. what you consider to be a "tld" is a (public or private) suffix plus the next domain name below. But that is not the "top level domain", it is first or second level (below the tld)! I think that deviation from standards should be documented *much* better.
2. you mix private and publix suffixes. So you treat e.g. `appspot.com` the same as `com` as equally valid suffixes! Have a look at the private suffix section in the list to see how much private domains are there.

items.title: Mixed up changelog entries?
items.body: Looking at the [differences between 0.7.9 and 0.7.10](https://github.com/barseghyanartur/tld/compare/0.7.9...0.7.10#diff-de0a9b67ffe2874a076b5fdb15bad484) we can see that the changelog entry of version 0.7.6 has been updated with exactly the content I would expect for 0.7.10.

items.title: [Bug] get_tld() fails to get root domain
items.body:
```
>>> from tld import get_tld
```

```
>>> get_tld("s3.amazonaws.com", fix_protocol=True)
u's3.amazonaws.com'
```

```
>>> get_tld("www.google.com", fix_protocol=True)
u'google.com'
```

items.title: Protocol relative url doesn't need to be fixed
items.body:
It is safe to use the `fix_protocol` parameter even when the url has proper protocol:
`>>> get_tld("http://www.google.co.uk")`
`'google.co.uk'`
`>>> get_tld("http://www.google.co.uk", fix_protocol=True)`
`'google.co.uk'`

But not in case of protocol relative url though it is valid for `urlparse`
`>>> get_tld("//www.google.co.uk")`
`'google.co.uk'`
`>>> get_tld("//www.google.co.uk", fix_protocol=True)`
`Traceback (most recent call last):`
`  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>`
`  File "/home/tomako/worx/poderio/poderio-cat/pyve/lib/python3.5/site-packages/tld/utils.py", line 178, in get_tld`
`    raise TldBadUrl(url=url)`
`tld.exceptions.TldBadUrl: Is not a valid URL https:////www.google.co.uk!`

items.title: Includes username/login info in the TLD
items.body:
First, thanks for making this package! It's solved a few problems for me. 👍 

I'm not sure if this is meant to be handled by this package or not, but I have a couple of domains I've tried to parse with this that are in the form of `http://foo@bar.com`, which I parse as:

```python
url = 'http://foo@bar.com'
res = get_tld(url, as_object=True, fix_protocol=True, fail_silently=True)
domain = res.tld
```

But `domain` will equal `foo@bar.com` here, I'd expect just `bar.com`.

Right now I'm just splitting on `@` if it exists and handling it, which is easy, but it seems weird to have a property called `domain` that includes this information. Feel free to close as out of scope if you want!

items.title: Allow custom NAMES_SOURCE_URL value
items.body:
Mozilla's MRX is suffering an outage, which makes updating the database impossible:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1279952

I think it would be nice if it was possible to force updating using a custom url, from a cloned mozilla-central repo or from an alternative url like `http://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/raw-file/tip/netwerk/dns/effective_tld_names.dat` which has higher availability than `mrx`. Or even use `https://publicsuffix.org/list/public_suffix_list.dat` which seems to be the official list.

Also, I was told in Mozilla's IRC that `mrx` is going to be deprecated soon in favor of drx.mozilla.org, so it's a good idea to change the default.

items.title: Capitalisation changes result
items.body:
```
In [2]: tld.get_tld("http://www.hec.Ac.ma")
Out[2]: 'Ac.ma'

In [3]: tld.get_tld("http://www.hec.ac.ma")
```
